sect1.title: 151 Less Common Helminths
sect1.para: This chapter covers the less common causes of helminthic parasitic infections, particularly those caused by the less common nematodes and cestodes. The less common medically important trematodes are discussed inchapter 150 of this Manual. This chapter is not comprehensive, given the wide variety of helminthic parasites that have been reported to cause human disease, but includes some of the most interesting and challenging parasitic diseases. Further information about these and other helminths of medical importance is available in Pathology of Infectious Diseases, volume 1, Helminthiasis, by the former Armed Forces Institute of Pathology (AFIP) (1); Pathology of Infectious Diseases (2); Ash & Orihel’s Atlas of Human Parasitology (3); and at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) parasitology diagnostic website (http://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Collection, transport, and storage of specimens are similar regardless of the type of helminth present, so guidelines are consolidated here to reduce duplication. Worms present in the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract, such asAnisakis or Capillaria, may be retrieved by endoscopy. Surgical resection specimens may contain a worm or larvae. The intact worm and surgical specimens may be preserved and transported in 60% ethanol or 10% neutral buffered formalin, with the former preferred for intact worms since formalin hardens the tissues of the worm. Stool is an important diagnostic specimen for parasites that reproduce within the intestinal tract, such as Capillaria philippinensis, and should be collected and fixed in a standard manner (e.g., formalin and polyvinyl alcohol), as described in chapter 137 of this Manual. Blood for serology should be handled in a standard manner. Additional information about serologic tests for the diagnosis of parasites covered in this chapter is also available through the CDC at https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/diagnosticprocedures/serum/tests.html.

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Ascaridida, and in the family Anisakidae.

sect2.title: Description of the Agents
sect2.para: Anisakis species, for which Anisakis simplex is the type species, Pseudoterranova decipiens, and Contracaecum species are covered in this section.

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: Marine mammals are the definitive hosts for anisakids; they become infected by ingesting larvae present in a variety of fish or squid (Fig. 1). A meta-analysis of 123 papers from over 5 decades, which included assessments of over 56,000 fish, suggests a significant increase over time in the abundance of Anisakis spp. but a stable number of Pseudoterranova spp. (4). This finding has been independently supported by studies evaluating the bioburden of Anisakis simplex L3 larvae in Atlantic salmon (5).

Human infections and allergic reactions occur when raw or undercooked infected fish is eaten (6). A single report claims possible transmission through the ingestion of clams (7). Humans are a dead-end host for anisakids, since the parasite is unable to reach reproductive maturity in this host.

Fish that has been salted, pickled, smoked, or marinated in lime juice (e.g., ceviche) may still contain viable anisakid larvae. The CDC recommends adequately cooking seafood, defined as cooking that reaches an internal temperature of at least 145°F (approximately 63°C), to prevent disease. Freezing can also render the seafood safe provided it is done appropriately. Freezing options include: –4°F (–20°C) or lower for 7 days; –31°F (–35°C) or lower until solid, then storage at the same temperature for 15 hours; or –31°F (–35°C) or lower until solid with storage at –4°F (–20°C) or lower for 24 hours (https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/anisakiasis/faqs.html#prevent).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Anisakid life cycle. Anisakids are gastric nematodes of marine mammals. Eggs that are released in the stool (step 1) embryonate (2a) and release larvae (2b) that infect crustaceans (3). The crustaceans are eaten by fish or cephalopod paratenic hosts (4), which eventually pass this parasite to the definitive host when it is eaten (5, 6). Humans become infected when eating raw or undercooked seafood that contains the parasite (7). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: The clinical features are caused by either the physical presence/migration of the larvae, or an allergic response to the parasite. Most commonly, patients experience nonspecific, acute abdominal pain from the physical presence of the worm within 12 hours after eating infected fish; allergic reactions may occur within this same timeframe (8, 9). Infections vary from asymptomatic to dysentery (10, 11). The larvae are associated with the superficial aspects of the mucosa in the early stages of disease, and with mucosal trauma caused by larval migration and the tissue reaction to the helminth. Larvae at this stage may migrate up the esophagus and cause coughing, potentially with expectoration of the worm; infestation of the palatine tonsil has been described (12). Anisakis has been incidentally discovered in the colon of an asymptomatic individual (10). Severe symptoms manifest if the worm penetrates through the mucosa into the submucosal and deeper tissues (Fig. 2). This evokes leukocytosis and eosinophilia (13). Sudden, intense abdominal pain may be mistaken for appendicitis, acute gastritis, gastric ulcer disease, or chronic colitis (e.g., Crohn’s disease) (14). Diarrhea and constipation may occur, and the stool may contain occult blood. Immunoglobulin E (IgE)-mediated hypersensitivity reactions to anisakids have been described and include acute urticaria and anaphylaxis (9, 15).

figure.title: FIGURE 2 This Anisakis species (arrows) has penetrated into the deep tissues of the abdomen. Multiple cross sections of the worm, which is 300 μm in diameter, are seen in the omentum. Movat stain; original magnification, ×2.5.

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: The intact worms, best visualized with a dissecting microscope, are white to cream, nonsegmented larvae that measure 10 to 50 mm by 0.3 to 1.2 mm. One dorsal and two subventral reduced lips and a triangular boring tooth are useful for identification. The mucron or tail spine is another useful feature for the identification ofAnisakis larvae. Both the boring tooth and mucron are useful features, but in some specimens these may be difficult to identify, which should not deter assigning the identification of an anasakid nematode. Histopathologic analysis of infected tissues often demonstrates cross sections of the worm and the host inflammatory response, which contains numerous eosinophils. The presence of Y-shaped lateral chords is useful for confirming the specimen as an anasakid worm. Cross-sectional studies are useful for identifying the type of anisakid present, but the precise genus and species designation is not necessary for treatment. Molecular- and protein-based methods of detection and characterization have been described; these are most commonly used in the food industry and are usually unnecessary for the diagnosis of human infection (16). Molecular characterization is useful for understanding species distributions, which provides insights for possible epidemiologic links. For example, molecular identification of anisakid larvae recovered by endoscopy from patients in South Korea identified all as Anisakis pegreffii, as were 90.7% of the larvae recovered from eels, supporting an epidemiologic association (17).

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Serologic tests to detect the immunologic response toAnisakis and related species are available at commercial reference laboratories in the United States. A variety of serologic assays have been developed, which vary in sensitivity and specificity. These identify 85 to 90% of infected individuals, with antibodies appearing from 10 to 35 days after infection. The specificity of these assays is limited predominantly because of cross-reactivity with other ascarids, which may limit the utility of these assays in certain populations (e.g., individuals with intestinal ascarids).

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: Removal of the larva via endoscopy, while it is associated only with the superficial mucosa, is the most efficacious treatment. Surgical resection, however, may be needed for more deeply insinuated larvae. Anthelmintic drugs do not appear to be useful, but corticosteroids may be used to decrease the associated inflammation (18). The CDC suggests that treatment with albendazole (i.e., 400 mg p.o. [orally], b.i.d. [twice per day], for 6 to 21 days) may be useful for patients with presumptive disease based on serology or dietary history (https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/anisakiasis/health_professionals/index.html).

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade I (Dorylaimia) of the Nematoda in the order Trichocephalida and the family Trichinellidae. A full explanation of the modern classification system is provided inchapter 136 of this Manual.

sect2.title: Description of the Agents
sect2.para: AlthoughTrichinella spiralis is the most important cause of human disease in this genus, there are a number of other Trichinella species, such as T. nativa, T. pseudospiralis, T. nelson, and T. britovi, that also cause trichinosis (19).

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: Trichinosis occurs worldwide (20). The life cycle of Trichinella spp. is different from most other nematodes in that the infected mammal both serves as the definitive host and harbors infective larvae encysted within muscle (i.e., serves as the intermediate host) (Fig. 3) (19). The domestic pig has historically been the most important host for the transmission of this roundworm to humans, where the parasitic cycle is propagated in the barnyard between pigs and rodents. Porcine transmission, however, has decreased significantly in areas with good animal husbandry practices (21). The meat of bears, walruses, and other wild game, including wild pigs and boars, may also contain infective larvae and is an important cause of human infection (21). Additionally, many other animals that are uncommon food sources, such as wolves, foxes, and raccoons, also harbor Trichinella (22). Disease may be prevented by eating only thoroughly cooked meat products of potential hosts and by attempting to control trichinosis in domesticated hosts through good animal husbandry practices. The CDC notes that pork cut to less than 6 inches thick may be rendered safe by freezing at 5°F (–15°C) for 20 days, but that some Trichinella species found in wild game meats are freeze resistant (https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/trichinellosis/prevent.html). Good food preparation practices, such as thoroughly washing cutting boards or meat grinders after use with raw meat, as well as good hand hygiene, are also important preventive measures.

figure.title: FIGURE 3 Trichinella life cycle. Humans may become infected by eating raw or undercooked pork or the meat of infected wild animals (step 1). Infection of animals is maintained in either domestic or sylvatic cycles. This nematode replicates within the small intestine of the infected human, resulting in the release of larvae that will encyst in muscle of the same individual (2 through 5). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: Infections vary from mild, subclinical disease to severe illness, depending on the parasite load. The clinical manifestations vary with the stage of infection. Gastrointestinal symptoms, associated with adult worms, last only about a week and include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Clinical findings include fever, facial edema that is particularly predominant around the eyes, ocular hyperemia with or without hemorrhage, headache, myalgia, and splinter hemorrhages under the nails (20, 23). These findings are associated with larval migration and encystment. Supportive laboratory findings include pronounced peripheral eosinophilia, leukocytosis, and elevated serum creatine phosphokinase levels (20, 23). If larval migration involves the brain and meninges, then neurologic symptoms predominate, whereas involvement of the myocardium causes myocarditis and possibly arrhythmias or sudden cardiac death. Unlike skeletal muscle, the larvae do not encyst in these other tissues. Experimental animal models and paired serologic data from infants born to infected women support the possibility of vertical transmission during pregnancy (24).

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: The direct microscopic examination of a muscle biopsy, performed by simply compressing the fresh muscle fibers between glass slides and observing the specimen microscopically, may disclose larvae encysted within a muscle cell, which is commonly known as a nurse cell. There are nonencysting species ofTrichinella, such as T. pseudospiralis, which invade the muscle cell but do not encyst. More commonly, larvae are detected by observing the infected tissues after histologic processing (i.e., in surgical pathology) (Fig. 4).

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid and Other Detection Techniques
sect2.para: Although nucleic acid amplification assays have been developed forTrichinella spiralis, these are not used clinically (25). These assays, as well as enzyme immunoassays and mass spectrometry, have been used for assessing the presence of this parasite in animal products, with the latter use recently demonstrated to be able to achieve species-level differentiation (26, 27).

sect2.title: Serology
sect2.para: The antibody response of patients with trichinellosis begins 3 to 5 weeks after infection in 80 to 100% of patients. Therefore, seroconversion following an acute illness is evidence of disease. The tests are highly sensitive, although less than 100% specific, with cross-reactivity usually occurring in patients with other helminth infections. Cross-reacting serologic reactions usually produce results in the equivocal range. These tests are available at the CDC and from several commercial laboratories.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: Therapy varies according to the stage of disease. Thiabendazole and albendazole are active against intestinal worms but, importantly, not against the encysted larvae. There is no proven method to kill the encysted larvae; however, microcrystallized forms of therapeutics, which act during the intestinal phase, are being assessed for decreasing the parasitic muscle burden (28). Corticosteroids, salicylates, and antihistamines may lessen symptoms associated with inflammation.

figure.title: FIGURE 4 This coiled first-stage T. spiralis larva is in a “nurse cell.” Note the hyaline, amorphous appearance of the external aspect of the nurse cell and the surrounding chronic inflammatory infiltrate. The worm diameter is 35 μm. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, ×30.

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Ascaridida, and in the family Toxocaridae.

sect2.title: Description of the Agents
sect2.para: Toxocara canis is the intestinal ascarid of dogs and other canids, whereas Toxocara cati is the intestinal ascarid of domestic cats and other felids. Both species can cause toxocariasis in humans.

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: Toxocariasis has a worldwide distribution, but the prevalence of this zoonotic disease varies widely by geographic area. The seroprevalence of human disease reflects helminthic control in dogs and cats. The highest infection rates occur among the poor, and there is an association with dog and cat ownership (29). Large surveys in the Netherlands associated with the evaluation of fecal specimens from 960 household dogs and 670 cats confirmed that younger animals were more likely to be infected, as were animals that were allowed to roam (30, 31).

The natural cycle ofToxocara begins with the passage of unembryonated eggs in the feces of the definitive host (Fig. 5). An infected animal passes a large number of eggs per day; for instance, an infected puppy may pass more than 10,000 eggs per g of feces (32). Therefore, one instance of stool contamination of the environment, such as in a sandbox, can cause significant contamination. The L2 (i.e., second-stage) larvae develop in the eggs after 10 to 20 days of incubation in the soil; the eggs at this stage are infective. If the eggs are ingested by a suitable definitive host, then the larvae penetrate the intestinal tract and migrate through the liver, bloodstream, and lungs. The larvae then migrate up the respiratory tract, are swallowed, and mature into adult worms in the intestinal tract. Paratenic hosts (e.g., rabbits) may also participate in the life cycle by harboring infective larvae after egg ingestion; ingestion of the paratenic host by the definitive host will allow the larvae to mature to adulthood. When the eggs are ingested by a nonpermissive host, such as a child, the resulting Toxocara larvae cannot complete their life cycle but rather wander aimlessly in the aberrant host, causing visceral larva migrans. Prevention is achieved foremost through zoonotic control by deworming dogs and cats. Deworming is most important for puppies, which are particularly permissive for infection and are often in close contact with children. Other preventive measures include avoidance of animal feces, thorough washing of fruits and vegetables, and thorough cooking of meats from potentially paratenic hosts (33).

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: Toxocara infections are common helminthic infections of humans. Fortunately, most infections are subclinical, producing only mild disease for which a definitive diagnosis is not sought. The most severe forms of disease occur with involvement of the eyes or significant involvement of the heart, liver, brain, or other vital organs (34). Symptomatic toxocariasis may have more generalized signs and symptoms (i.e., common toxocariasis), affect deep viscera (i.e., visceral larva migrans), or particularly affect the eyes (i.e., ocular larva migrans) or central nervous system (i.e., cerebral toxocariasis) (34).

figure.title: FIGURE 5 The Toxocara life cycle. This life cycle demonstrates the natural cycle of Toxocara within dogs and cats (steps 1 through 6), as well as the involvement of paratenic hosts (i.e., the rabbit and duck in this image, step 7). The cycle is completed within canines and felines through either the ingestion of eggs (3) or the consumption of an infected paratenic host (8). Humans become infected either through the direct ingestion of fertilized and embryonated eggs (9) or through the ingestion of improperly processed meat from paratenic hosts (10), with the resulting larva migrans (11). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: Eggs are not produced in the human in toxocariasis, so a stool evaluation is not helpful for diagnosis. However, occasionally the eggs of another geohelminth, such asAscaris, hookworm, or Trichuris, may be present because of common risk factors. The detection of the migrating larvae in surgically excised tissues by histopathologic evaluation provides the definitive morphological diagnosis, but larvae are not always present in biopsy specimens. When present, the single minute lateral ala and the cross-sectional diameter are useful criteria for identifying these parasites in histologic sections (Fig. 6) (35).

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Serologic studies are important for the establishment of the diagnosis of toxocariasis; results of these studies should be used in conjunction with clinical findings as well as other laboratory findings, such as increased IgE and eosinophilia (36). Positive results in the absence of other corroborative findings could represent a previous, asymptomatic infection or cross-reactivity due to another helminth infection. The sensitivity and specificity of these assays are high but less than 100%. It is difficult to determine the precise parameters of serologic assays since there is not a better parasitological test (i.e., a gold standard) to confirm the presence of a true infection. These tests are useful in seroepidemiologic studies and have demonstrated that infection rates are significantly underestimated (37). Tests are available at the CDC and from commercial reference laboratories.

figure.title: FIGURE 6 The minute lateral alae are useful in the identification of Toxocara species. The worm diameter is 18 μm. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, ×500.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: There is no proven therapy. Anthelmintic therapy with albendazole or a similar therapeutic is often used, with claims of increased efficacy with long-term treatment (38). Corticosteroids may be necessary to control the inflammatory response in patients with a large parasite burden. Treatment for eye infections requires a combined medical and surgical approach (39).

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: Dracunculus medinensis, in the modern classification of biological species, is in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Camallanida, and in family Dracunculidae.

sect2.title: Description of the Agent
sect2.para: D. medinensis, also known as the Guinea worm, is a unique nematode in the order Camallanida. Eight species of Dracunculus have been described, but only D. medinensis infects humans. The other species infect snakes, turtles, and other mammals (40).

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: Human dracunculiasis is found only in the rural parts of Africa. Infections occur more commonly in the dry season and affect men more commonly than women. Individuals of a wide age range (i.e., 10 to 60 years old) are affected, which adversely affects the productivity of communities in areas of endemicity. An ongoing and intensive effort by the World Health Organization, the Carter Center, CDC, local governments, and numerous other humanitarian organizations has significantly decreased the annual incidence of disease (41). When eradication efforts began in 1986, an estimated 3.5 million people were infected with the Guinea worm (41). This number has been reduced to only 54 cases reported in 2019 (41). Although excellent progress has been made, efforts to completely eradicate this parasite have been difficult and new challenges have been recognized (41, 42). Updates and additional information are available from the WHO and CDC at the respective websites (i.e., https://www.who.int/health-topics/dracunculiasis#tab=tab_1).

Infection follows the consumption of freshwater copepods, usually in drinking water that harbors the infective larvae (Fig. 7). After ingestion, the larvae migrate to the retroperitoneum, where they mature and mate. The female worm eventually migrates to a subcutaneous location, where a blister forms. The blister bursts on contact with water and releases numerous larvae. The larvae are ingested by a copepod, in which they become infective. Preventive measures are centered on education and providing clean drinking water.

Currently, ongoing transmission is present in six countries: Angola, Chad, Ethiopia, Mali, South Sudan, and importations into Cameroon (41). Political unrest and war have hampered eradication efforts, as well as the recognition of canine infections. The COVID-19 pandemic has necessitated the deviation of limited resources from the so-called neglected tropical diseases (https://www.who.int/teams/control-of-neglected-tropical-diseases/overview/ntds-and-covid-19). Frogs may serve as paratenic hosts and fish as transport hosts, which has also complicated eradication efforts (41, 42). The discovery in Chad that dogs may serves as an alternate definitive host represents a new and significant challenge to eradication efforts (43).

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: Patients are often asymptomatic during larval penetration of the gastrointestinal tract and the retroperitoneal maturation and mating of the worms. Symptoms at this phase are secondary to inflammation and tissue damage caused by worm migration. Although lesions are most common in the lower extremities, they may occur anywhere in the body. The migrating worm produces a serpiginous tract under the skin (Fig. 8). The large blister that is formed may become secondarily infected. Dead worms may be absorbed, calcify, or produce symptoms secondary to location (e.g., arthritis due to involvement of a joint).

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: The presence of the end of a worm protruding from a burst blister or ulcer in the appropriate setting is usually diagnostic. However, a cutaneous manifestation of sparganosis is in the differential diagnosis (44). The microscopic analysis of these worms in cross section demonstrates a 30- to 50-μm-thick cuticle, indistinct lateral cords, prominent dorsal and ventral bands of smooth muscle, and a large uterus filled with rhabditoid larvae that fills the body cavity (Fig. 9); these findings definitively differentiate Dracunculus from the agents of sparganosis.

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Serologic tests are usually not necessary for diagnosis, given the obvious findings in people at risk for disease. However, seroprevalence studies are useful to identify infected individuals prior to the partial emergence of the adult worm.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: The oldest and traditional treatment, as depicted in an ancient Egyptian medical text, the Papyrus Ebers, consists of removing the gravid worm by wrapping the exposed end of the worm around a stick and applying gentle pressure each day for a number of days, until the worm is removed. Treatment with thiabendazole and metronidazole, although not lethal for the worm, may facilitate removal by this process (45). Although it is often effective, risks include rupture or breaking of the worm prior to full removal, which would leave a portion of the dead worm in the patient which acts as an inflammatory nidus. Currently, surgical excision is preferred (46). Anti-inflammatory agents and antihistamines are important for symptomatic relief. Antibiotics may be necessary to curtail secondary bacterial infections, and tetanus vaccination is important.

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade I (Dorylaimia) of the Nematoda, in the order Trichocephalida, and in the family Capillariidae.

figure.title: FIGURE 7 The Dracunculus medinensis life cycle. This image demonstrates the contraction of infection by humans and dogs through the direct ingestion of infected copepods or the ingestion of paratenic and/or transport hosts (e.g., frogs and fish) (steps 1a and 1b). Ingested larvae then migrate to a subcutaneous location, mature, and mate (2, 3). Extrusion of the posterior end of the female worm releases larvae into freshwater (4), where they infect copepods and complete the cycle (5, 6). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).
FIGURE 8 The serpiginous tract of a female D. medinensis worm is demonstrated in the scrotum of this patient.

FIGURE 9 Rhabditiform larvae (short arrow) fill the body cavity of this gravid D. medinensis worm. Also note the presence of the two prominent bands of somatic muscle (long arrow). The worm diameter is 1.1 mm. Movat stain; original magnification, ×25.

sect2.title: Description of the Agent
sect2.para: Capillaria philippinensis is a trichurid nematode responsible for intestinal capillariasis (47, 48). Other Capillaria species (C. hepatica and C. aerophila), which are less common causes of human disease, are not discussed further.

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: The natural parasitic cycle ofC. philippinensis involves fish as the intermediate hosts (Fig. 10). Marine, fish-eating birds are thought by some to serve as the definitive host, but this has not been confirmed. Disease is endemic to the Philippines, Thailand, and other parts of Asia and has more recently spread to Upper Egypt (49). The means by which C. philippinensis has spread to Egypt is unknown, but the importation of infected live fish or the carriage of the parasite in infected migratory birds has been postulated (49). Humans become infected by ingesting raw or undercooked fish that harbor the infective larvae. Adults, eggs, and larvae at various stages of maturation may be found in the lumen of the intestine of the definitive host. This parasite may reinfect the intestinal mucosa, thereby completing its life cycle within a single host. This feature affords the production of a hyperinfection with devastating consequences. Thorough cooking of fish is protective.

figure.title: FIGURE 10 The Capillaria philippinensis life cycle. Infection proceeds following the ingestion of infected and undercooked fish (step 4). This nematode can complete sexual reproduction within the human host (step 5), releasing larvae capable of reinfection (6, 7) and thereby establishing an autoinfective cycle. Unembryonated eggs are also produced and released in the feces (1). These embryonate in the water (step 2) and, when ingested by fish, release the larvae that infect the intermediate fish host (3). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: Infections withC. philippinensis are thought to be relatively rare, but may be significantly underestimated given the poor sensitivity of microscopy (50). Nonspecific gastrointestinal complaints predominate early in the course of disease; these include watery diarrhea (which often occurs at night), abdominal pain, and weakness (51). As the disease progresses and the number of worms increases, there is continued diarrhea and malabsorption leading to edema, weight loss, and eventual cachexia (51). Death occurs secondarily to malnutrition, electrolyte abnormalities, and the sequelae thereof, or because of secondary bacterial infections (e.g., septicemia).

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: Microscopic examination of the stool may demonstrate a mixture of eggs, larvae, and adult parasites. The likelihood of finding an adult in the stool is proportional to the degree of hyperinfection. The larvae ofCapillaria demonstrate stichocytes, which are useful in differentiating these from other larvae such as Strongyloides (48). A comparison of microscopic examination (repeated up to three times if the first two specimens were negative), Copro-ELISA, and Copro-PCR demonstrated that detection rates may be as low as 24% (50). The eggs of C. philippinensis (Fig. 11), which have bipolar plugs, are superficially reminiscent of the more commonly recognized trichurid worm, Trichuris trichiura. The plugs of C. philippinensis, however, are non-protruding, the egg is more rectangular, and there is a distinctive pitting of the eggshell, which imparts a striated appearance (52). The adult worms superficially resemble Strongyloides stercoralis but may be differentiated by the presence of stichocytes and three bacillary bands, with the latter being recognized most easily in cross-section.

figure.title: FIGURE 11 The bipolar plugs (arrows), pitted eggshell, and rectangular shape characteristic of Capillaria philippinensis. This photomicrograph is from a human small intestine and demonstrates an egg that is 40 μm long. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, ×490.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid and Other Detection Techniques
sect2.para: Emerging data suggest that enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) performed on stool are highly sensitive, but lack specificity (50). Although a stool-based PCR assay may not be quite as sensitive as a stool-based ELISA, the specificity appears higher (50). The combination of one or both of these with stool microscopy may produce an optimal diagnostic algorithm. Unfortunately, neither ELISA antigen detection tests or nucleic acid amplification tests are readily available for the detection of Capillaria.

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Serologic tests are not available from the CDC or from commercial reference laboratories in the United States. An ELISA for the screening of sera for antibodies directed againstC. philippinensis has been developed and is reported to have high sensitivity and specificity (53). This assay is particularly useful in infected patients who are negative by conventional stool examination. Cross-reactivity may occur when other helminthic infections are present, as with the stool-based ELISA, which may affect the specificity of the assay.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: Albendazole, mebendazole, or thiabendazole may be used for therapy. Relapsing disease requires prolonged anthelmintic therapy. Aggressive electrolyte replacement and monitoring are critical, as are control of diarrhea and administration of nutrients.

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Spirurida, and in the family Gnathostomatidae.

sect2.title: Description of the Agents
sect2.para: Gnathostoma species are gastric spirurid nematode parasites for which the definitive hosts are a variety of mammals, not including humans (54). Infective L3 (i.e., third-stage) larvae predominantly cause disease in humans, but it is also thought that L2 (i.e., second-stage) larvae encountered in infected copepods in unclean drinking water may also cause disease. Gnathostoma infections result in cutaneous and/or visceral larva migrans, the latter of which may include ocular and/or central nervous system manifestations. Gnathostoma spinigerum is the most common cause of human disease, but human infections by other species have also been reported.

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: Gnathostoma spinigerum has essentially a worldwide distribution, with dogs and cats serving as the primary definitive hosts (Fig. 12). Gnathostoma hispidum and G. doloresi infect wild and domestic pigs, whereas G. nipponicum is a parasite of weasels.

The adult male and female gnathostomes live in a tumor produced in the gastric wall of the definitive host, where they mate and produce eggs. The eggs are passed in the stool, and once in water, hatch and release first-stage larvae. These infect the copepodCyclops and mature into second-stage larvae. When a variety of intermediate hosts, such as fish, snakes, eels, or frogs, eat the copepod, the larvae penetrate the gastric wall of the new host, where they develop into third-stage larvae (L3), migrate to the musculature, and encyst. When a definitive host eats the intermediate host, the L3 larvae excyst, penetrate the gastric wall, and subsequently migrate through the liver, muscles, and connective tissues, only to return to the stomach to mature into adults. Alternatively, paratenic hosts such as birds may eat the second intermediate host; the ingested L3 larvae remain viable in the paratenic host and may be transmitted either to the definitive host or to humans.

figure.title: FIGURE 12 The Gnathostoma life cycle. Gnathostoma species infect a variety of mammals, forming a parasitic tumor in the stomach. Eggs that are passed in the feces (step 1) release larvae (2) that infect copepods (3), which are the first intermediate host. These are ingested by fish or frogs (4), which are the second intermediate host. The definitive host becomes infected by ingesting second intermediate host tissue (step 5) or paratenic host tissue (6). Humans also become infected through the ingestion of raw or undercooked meat from either a second intermediate or paratenic host. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.para: This parasite is transmitted to humans through the ingestion of raw or undercooked meat from a secondary intermediate host or a paratenic host. Humans are accidental hosts, in which the nematode larvae cannot mature to adulthood and continue to migrate aimlessly and aggressively (54). Disease can be prevented by thoroughly cooking potentially infected foods.

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: The clinical presentations of gnathostomiasis are protean because the wandering larvae may be present in any tissue or organ system (55–58). Although the infection is not commonly fatal, significant morbidity may result. The clinical manifestations depend on the tissues in which the larva is migrating. Panniculitis, creeping eruptions, and pseudofurunculosis are dermatologic manifestations of gnathostomiasis (56). Any visceral organ may be affected, including the eyes and central nervous system (57, 58).

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: The L3 larvae, rather than the mature (adult) gnathostomes, are present in humans. This form is morphologically similar to the adult form but smaller, measuring 3 to 4 mm in length by approximately 630μm in diameter (G. spinigerum). The head bulb contains four rows of cephalic hooklets, with approximately 45 hooklets per row. The body of the larva, like that of the adult, is covered with transverse rows of sharply pointed spines that diminish toward the posterior end of the worm. An entire worm may be expelled spontaneously from the site of infection or may require surgical excision.

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Serologic assays have been developed predominantly in areas of endemicity. These are not available in the United States, but the CDC can assist in identifying a source for testing, if necessary. The possibility of cross-reactivity should be considered with these tests and with other serologic assays for helminthic parasites.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: Surgical removal of the parasite is the most effective treatment, but it is difficult to achieve because of parasite migration; this may be aided by advanced imaging tools (59). Treatment usually involves some type of anthelmintic medication, such as albendazole or ivermectin. There remains controversy regarding the treatment of central nervous system gnathostomiasis, because there is a concern that anthelmintic therapy will kill the invading worms and increase the inflammatory reaction; treatment is supportive and may include corticosteroid use to control the inflammatory response (60).

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade V (Chromadoria: Rhabditina) of the Nematoda, in the order Rhabditida (Strongylida), and in the family Ancylostomatidae. There is ongoing discussion regarding the nomenclature of this parasite (i.e.,Parastrongylus versus Angiostrongylus).

sect2.title: Description of the Agents
sect2.para: Parastrongylus cantonensis and P. costaricensis are filariform worms that cause neural and abdominal parastrongyliasis, respectively (60, 61).

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: Parastrongylus spp. are widely distributed throughout the world and represent an important public health threat, particularly in Southeast Asia, the Asian Pacific Islands, Africa, and the Caribbean. Outbreaks have occurred in Hawaii, and a 10-year review of infections in this state has been reported (62).These parasites persist in a wide variety of rodents, which serve as the definitive host. The adult worms of Parastrongylus cantonensis reside in the pulmonary artery and the right side of the heart of the rodent, whereas the adults of P. costaricensis reside in arterioles in the ileum. Eggs released from the adult worms lodge in capillaries, where they hatch and release larvae. The larvae subsequently migrate up the trachea, are swallowed, and are passed in the feces. These larvae infect mollusks, particularly snails and slugs, which are the intermediate host. Within the snail, they mature into the infective L3 larvae. A number of animals, including shrimp, crabs, fish, and frogs, that eat the infected mollusks serve as important paratenic hosts. Rodents that ingest either the infected mollusk or tissues from the paratenic host become infected. In the definitive host, the infective larvae penetrate the intestine, become bloodborne, and migrate to the central nervous system, where they molt twice. Thereafter, the worms reenter the systemic circulation and finally reside in either the right ventricle and pulmonary artery (P. cantonensis) or the ileum (P. costaricensis) to mature and complete the cycle.

Humans become infected through the ingestion of tissue from an infected mollusk, an infected paratenic host, and, although controversial, possibly through excretions from snails or slugs (i.e., slime) that contaminate other foodstuffs (e.g., vegetables) (Fig. 13). Prevention of disease can be achieved through control of the local rat population, the thorough cooking of mollusks and meat from paratenic hosts, and the washing of vegetables that may be contaminated with small snails or slugs or their slime.

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: The clinical manifestations reflect the worm burden and the site of worm residence: the central nervous system forP. cantonensis and the ileocecal region for P. costaricensis. The worms of P. cantonensis usually remain juvenile, tend to remain associated with the brain and meninges in human infections (Fig. 14), and often die in this location. Conversely, P. costaricensis often reaches sexual maturity in the arterioles of the ileum and releases eggs into intestinal tissue, but these do not pass into the lumen. Patients with central nervous system disease demonstrate signs and symptoms typical of meningitis or meningoencephalitis, with headache, fever, possibly eosinophilia (10 to 60%), and a variety of neurologic disturbances, depending on the location of the worms. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) demonstrates pleocytosis, eosinophilia (26 to 75%), and elevated protein and occasionally will contain immature worms. Alternatively, patients may have infections of the eye, with retinal detachment and blindness. Less commonly, human infections may result in pulmonary disease. Infections with P. costaricensis result in eosinophilic enteritis with diarrhea and abdominal pain.

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: Demonstration of the worms in histologic sections or intact in clinical specimens from the CSF, eye, or other infected tissue definitively establishes the diagnosis. Eosinophilia in the CSF may be the first indicator of a possible parasitic infection of the central nervous system. The differential diagnosis of the causes of CSF eosinophilia, however, is broad and includes other parasitic infections, e.g., withGnathostoma or Toxocara spp., allergic reactions, and coccidioidomycosis. The gross appearance of an adult female worm is distinctive, with the spiral winding of the uteri and ovarian branches imparting a “barber pole” appearance. Cross section of the female demonstrates a large intestine and two uteri, whereas cross section of the male reveals a large intestine and a single reproductive tract. Eggs are not produced in human tissues by P. cantonensis, whereas they may be produced by P. costaricensis. The eggs of P. costaricensis remain embedded in tissue in the human host and do not appear in stool. The eggs are oval and thin-shelled, somewhat resemble a hookworm egg, and usually measure 60 to 65 by 40 to 45 μm.

figure.title: FIGURE 13 The Parastrongylus (Angiostrongylus) cantonensis life cycle. Infection is maintained in the wild between rodents and snails (steps 1 through 4). Humans become infected through the accidental ingestion of snails or contaminated produce. Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 14 The immature P. cantonensis worm (arrows) in the meninges of this patient is eliciting a marked eosinophilic response. The worm is 200 μm in diameter. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, ×50.

sect2.title: Serologic and Molecular Diagnostic Tests
sect2.para: Antibody detection assays have limited value in acute infections, but may prove useful for seroepidemiologic studies, as antibodies are often present in convalescent-phase sera (63). The serologic assays that have been developed vary with respect to sensitivity and specificity, so it is important that the user understand the performance characteristics and the limitations of the assay under consideration (64). Although intrathecal antibody is not always produced during infection, the presence of intrathecal antibody synthesis, when detected, provides strong evidence of infection. This assay is available from some commercial laboratories in the United States. Antigen detection assays have also been developed, which hold promise (63). The CDC offers a PCR test for P. cantonensis on CSF that may prove the most useful assay if this infection is suspected.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: An optimal treatment has not been established. Fortunately, the disease is often self-limited. Removal of CSF, to decrease intracranial pressure, and the administration of corticosteroids and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents have been used to control pain and inflammation. A variety of anthelmintic medications have been used, with mebendazole being the current drug of choice and albendazole as an alternative. Careful monitoring of the patient is important since anthelmintic therapy may sometimes exacerbate the symptoms (65). Corticosteroids may be used alone or in combination with anthelmintic therapy (65).

sect1.title: Dirofilaria immitis and Other Dirofilaria Species

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Spirurida, and in the family Onchocercidae.

sect2.title: Description of the Agents
sect2.para: The filarial dog heartworm,Dirofilaria immitis, has a worldwide distribution; when infections occur in humans, they cause pulmonary dirofilariasis (66). There are a variety of other Dirofilaria species that may also accidentally infect humans. Dirofilaria tenuis is a raccoon parasite common in the southeast United States, D. ursi infects bears in the northern United States and Canada, and D. repens is a dog parasite restricted to the Old World (67, 68).

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: Although dogs are the most important host forD. immitis, other mammals, such as foxes and bears, are also suitable hosts. It is, therefore, important that dogs should be regularly dewormed. The blood of infected suitable hosts contains microfilariae that are released from the adult worm, which resides in the right ventricle of the heart. These are taken into the mosquito during a blood meal, wherein they mature into infective L3 larvae and are capable of transfer to another mammal during a blood meal. The larvae migrate through subcutaneous tissues and eventually enter the bloodstream and the right side of the heart, where they mature into adults in a permissive host (Fig. 15). Humans, however, are unsuitable or nonpermissive hosts. The worm dies in human infections before it reaches maturity and is swept into the pulmonary arterial circulation (Fig. 16 and 17). It subsequently lodges in the subsegmental pulmonary arteries and arterioles and causes thrombosis, infarction, inflammation, and eventually a granulomatous reaction surrounded by a wall of fibrous tissue.

The geographic distribution of disease reflects the prevalence of canine dirofilariasis. The areas of highest prevalence in the United States are in the South, particularly along the Gulf and Atlantic coasts and along the Mississippi River (68). Dirofilaria immitis is widely distributed, also occurring throughout South and Central America, Australia, and the South Pacific islands, as well as in parts of Europe, Russia, and Africa (66). Interestingly, dog ownership is not a risk factor for disease. Prevention is centered on the control of zoonotic disease. The use of mosquito repellents, particularly in areas of high endemicity, is also recommended to interrupt transmission.

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: Slightly more than half of the patients with dirofilariasis are asymptomatic. The findings in symptomatic patients are nonspecific symptoms, such as cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, low-grade fever, chills, and malaise (69). Peripheral eosinophilia is present in only 5 to 10% of patients. In addition to pulmonary manifestations, D. immitis has also rarely been identified in subcutaneous abscesses, the abdominal cavity, the eyes, and the testes. However, it is more likely that Dirofilaria species other than D. immitis are found in a subcutaneous locations (Table 1). A critical review of human pulmonary dirofilariasis in the Old World suggested, on the basis of traditional morphologic findings, that pulmonary dirofilariasis in these geographic regions may more likely be caused by a Dirofilaria species other than D. immitis, namely D. repens (70). The nodules caused by D. immitis are often discovered by a routine chest radiograph, appearing as a solitary nodule or “coin lesion.” These usually need to be excised, or otherwise assessed (e.g., biopsied) to exclude malignancy (68). These nodules are usually single, but occasionally two or three nodules may be present.

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: The pulmonary nodules produced byD. immitis are characteristically small (0.8 to 4.5 cm; mean, 1.9 cm), subpleural, spherical, and well circumscribed. Dirofilaria immitis has a smooth, thick cuticle (5 to 25 μm) with the three distinct layers characteristic of the genus Dirofilaria. Other Dirofilaria species that infect humans have a similar trilaminar cuticle but with external longitudinal ridges (Fig. 18). The thick, multilayered cuticle projects inwardly at the lateral chords, forming two prominent, opposing internal longitudinal ridges. The somatic musculature is typically prominent, but the lateral chords are usually poorly preserved. Transverse sections may reveal two large uteri and a much smaller intestine in female worms (Fig. 18); a single reproductive tract and an intestine are present in males. The definitive identification of the worm based on internal structures may be difficult or impossible, given the advanced stage of parasite degeneration in many of these specimens. The presence of a parasitic worm in a pulmonary artery and in association with a pulmonary infarct, however, is usually sufficient for a diagnosis.

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Serologic tests to detect antibody toDirofilaria are commercially available from several reference laboratories. Although advances have been made to increase specificity without sacrificing sensitivity, cross-reactivity may occur in patients infected with other nematodes, particularly other filarial worms. As with many serologic assays, a positive test is useful, whereas a negative test does not exclude the possibility of infection.

figure.title: FIGURE 16 The coiled remnants of an immature male D. immitis worm are present in this branch of the pulmonary artery. The maximum worm diameter is 250 μm. Movat stain; original magnification, ×15.

FIGURE 15 The Dirofilaria immitis life cycle. The mosquito functions as the vector for the dog heartworm (steps 1 through 8). Humans become infected when bitten by a mosquito harboring the parasite larva (9). (9). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 17 The two uteri (arrows), muscle, and trilaminar and smooth cuticle (arrowhead) are characteristic of an immature female D. immitis worm. Internal cuticular projections can be helpful in identifying dead or dying worms. The worm diameter is 250 μm. Movat stain; original magnification, ×80.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: Excision of the nodule is curative. The organism is usually already dead, so antiparasitic therapy is not necessary. Removal of the worm is imperative for ocular dirofilariasis. The worm typically resides in the sclera/subconjunctiva and is readily extracted by an ophthalmologist.

row.entry: Zoonotic hookworms (e.g.,Ancylostoma ceylanicum, A. caninum, A. braziliense, and Uncinaria stenocephala)
Clinical findings or, rarely, detection of larvae in biopsy of skin
Dirofilaria species other than D. immitis: D. tenuis, D. repens, D. ursi, D. subdermata, and D. striata
Raccoons (D. tenuis), dogs and cats (D. repens), bears (D. ursi), porcupines (D. subdermata), wild cats (D. striata)
Mosquitoes, except forD. ursi, which is transmitted by black flies
Usually subcutaneous nodules that contain mature, immature, or degenerated worms
Morphological features of the worm in excised tissues (Fig. 18)

figure.title: FIGURE 18 Dirofilaria species other than D. immitis have external longitudinal cuticular ridges, whereas the cuticle of D. immitis is smooth. Dirofilaria tenuis, pictured here in cross section, is 270 μm in diameter and has obvious cuticular ridges (arrows). Dirofilaria species other than D. immitis are often found in a subcutaneous location rather than in the pulmonary arterial vasculature. Movat stain; original magnification, ×80.

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: Baylisascaris species are in clade III (Chromadoria: Spururina) of the Nematoda, in the order Ascaridida, and in the family Ascarididae in the modern classification of biological species.

sect2.title: Description of the Agent
sect2.para: Baylisascaris procyonis is the roundworm of the raccoon (Procyon lotor) and the most important human pathogen of this genus. Although other Baylisascaris species exist, these have been only rarely associated with sporadic disease. The adults of Baylisascaris are large, tan roundworms; the smaller males measure 9 to 11 cm in length, whereas the larger females measure 20 to 22 cm in length (71).

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: B. procyonis is as widespread as its definitive host, the North American raccoon. Although originally endemic only to North America, raccoons with this parasite have been exported worldwide as zoo animals, as fur-producing animals, or as pets, which is discouraged (71).

Young raccoons usually become infected through the direct ingestion of eggs, which are sometimes adherent to the fur of the mother raccoon (Fig. 19). Mature raccoons are more commonly infected through the ingestion of infected animals, such as woodchucks, rabbits, and rodents, which are paratenic hosts that develop larva migrans when infected (72). Interestingly, if the paratenic host does not die of the larva migrans, the disease makes the animal more susceptible to opportunistic predation by raccoons. After ingestion, migration, and maturation, male and female worms develop in the small intestine of the raccoon and mate.

It has been estimated that the adult female produces between 115,000 and 179,000 eggs/worm/day (73). An infected raccoon passes 20,000 to 26,000 eggs per g of feces (EGF), with extremes of more than 250,000 EGF recorded (73). In addition to the high level of egg production, there is an enhanced risk of infection by B. procyonis compared with other Baylisascaris species because of the behavior of the raccoon host. Raccoons are known to defecate in specific locations, known as raccoon latrines, which results in the accumulation of a large quantity of fecal matter (73). This creates a high-risk area for contracting infection. Sandboxes and garden plots are common locations for latrines, and are locations where young children may contract the infection. It is for this reason, as well as the use of sandboxes by cats, that sandboxes should be covered when not in use, if possible.

Transmission occurs through the ingestion of material contaminated with egg-containing raccoon feces. The eggs ofBaylisascaris are highly resistant to desiccation, remaining viable for years in the environment, long after the physical evidence of the presence of a raccoon latrine has been removed by environmental factors (e.g., rain) (72). Children, particularly male children for some reason, are most commonly infected (71, 72). The feces of raccoons may contain seeds and other objects of temptation for a young child, and pica is a common risk factor for infection (71, 72). Only larval stages of Baylisascaris are present in tissues, as this nematode cannot mature into the adult form in humans.

figure.title: FIGURE 19 The Baylisascaris procyonis life cycle. Baylisascaris is a geohelminth of raccoons and occasionally other animals. Although ingestion of embryonated eggs by the raccoon is the primary mode of transmission, larvae also may persist in small animal paratenic hosts (steps 1 through 6). Humans become infected through the inadvertent ingestion of embryonated eggs (steps 8 and 9). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

sect2.para: Although control of the local raccoon population is a preventive measure, this is often difficult to achieve, as these animals live and thrive near human habitats. Behaviors that encourage raccoons, such as feeding and uncovered trash bins, should be avoided. Awareness of the medical importance of raccoon latrines and their careful clearing, as well as keeping young children away from such areas, are important preventive measures.

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: Baylisascaris procyonis readily infects humans and a variety of other animals, causing visceral, ocular, and neural larva migrans. Although less than 10% of the infecting larvae are thought to reach the brain, those that do produce severe disease because of their large size and aggressive migratory behavior (74). Six (40%) infections were fatal in a series of 15 reported patients; seven (47%) patients that survived were characterized as having severe neurologic deficits, and five were blind (72).

The history of a child entering and possibly eating material from a raccoon latrine is of paramount importance but may not be remembered, thought important, or even known by the parents. The presence of peripheral eosinophilia, eosinophilia of the CSF, and deep white matter changes on radiologic imaging are all clues to baylisascariasis in a child with unexplained meningoencephalomyelitis (72, 75, 76). Prompt anthelmintic and anti-inflammatory therapy should be given prior to the establishment of a definitive diagnosis (see below), and serologic studies should be sent for confirmation.

In addition to the devastating presentations described, serologic studies suggest that low-level infections producing subclinical disease, likely from ingestion of a small inoculum, may be more common than is appreciated (71, 77).

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: Direct examination and microscopy play a minor role in the prompt clinical diagnosis of baylisascariasis. Occasionally, if a biopsy is performed, the migrating larvae may be seen. The migrating larvae ofBaylisascaris are 60 to 80 μm in diameter and have a central intestine that is flanked on each side by a triangular lateral excretory column in midbody transverse section; a single lateral cuticular ala is located on each side of the larva (73). These features are sufficient to differentiate Baylisascaris from other causes of larva migrans. Unfortunately, not all biopsy specimens contain larvae, given the migratory nature of the larvae. The autopsy remains important to determine the cause of death for patients with fatal meningoencephalomyelitis of undetermined etiology.

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Serologic studies are the most important laboratory tools to establish the diagnosis of baylisascariasis. These are available through the CDC as well as through the Department of Veterinary Pathobiology at Purdue University (71). Although baylisascariasis is rare and large studies have not been performed, the serologic assays appear sufficiently sensitive to detect and confirm patients with infection. Importantly, the improved assays that target the RAG1 protein (rBpRAG1) are highly specific, without cross-reactivity with specimens from patients with larva migrans caused by Toxocara (78).

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: Mortality is high for patients with baylisascariasis, and significant long-term morbidity occurs in most patients who survive a serious clinical infection. Awareness of the possibility of this infection is critical for prompt therapy. Importantly, there is some evidence that treatment with albendazole in the very early stages of infection may reduce or eliminate the possibility of neural larva migrans (70, 79). This therapeutic opportunity, unfortunately, is often missed, and the possibility of this infection is not considered early in the patient evaluation.

The diagnosis, in most instances, is not considered until severe disease is established and other causes of encephalomyelitis have been excluded. Albendazole is recommended at the advanced stage of disease, but even with treatment, prognosis is poor; albendazole is often given in conjunction with corticosteroids (67). When ocular larva migrans is the predominant presentation, the direct photocoagulation of the larvae can be performed by an experienced ophthalmologist (72).

sect1.title: Other Less Common Nematodes
sect1.para: There are a number of less common nematodes other than those described here. Some of these and their important associated features are included inTable 1.

sect2.title: LESS COMMON CESTODES
sect2.para: Spirometra species, the etiologic agent of sparganosis, is the only less common cestode that is covered in detail here. Descriptions of a few of the other less common cestodes that may infect humans are given below (Table 2).

sect2.title: Taxonomy
sect2.para: The organisms in this group, in the modern classification of biological species, are in the Cestoda, in the order Pseudophyllidea, and in the family Diphyllobothriidae.

sect2.title: Description of the Agents
sect2.para: Sparganosis is the infection of humans by L3 plerocercoid larvae of a pseudophyllidean tapeworm (80). The plerocercoid larva in a human host does not reach maturity and is known as a sparganum. The tapeworms that cause sparganosis are Spirometra mansoni, S. mansonoides, S. ranarum, and S. erinacei. The precise taxonomic relationship of a cestode known as Sparganum proliferum, which causes a similar disease, is unclear, but this organism may simply represent a variant of S. mansonoides or S. erinacei. Additional information concerning this organism can also be found in chapter 149 of this Manual.

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: AdultSpirometra species are widely distributed tapeworms of animals, particularly dogs and cats (81). The parasitic cycle for these worms begins with the passage of eggs from an infected definitive host (Fig. 20). The coracidium that emerges from the egg infects the first intermediate host, a copepod. The second intermediate host, which includes snakes, frogs, and fish, becomes infected by ingesting the infected copepod. The cycle is completed when a permissive (i.e., definitive) host ingests the second intermediate host. Humans are nonpermissive hosts and may become infected by ingesting raw or undercooked meat from a second intermediate host or by drinking contaminated water that contains the infected copepod. Humans have also become infected by using infected animal flesh (e.g., frog flesh) as a poultice (81).

sect2.title: Clinical Significance
sect2.para: The results of ingesting a plerocercoid larva depend on both the species of the host and the species of the larva. For example, the ingestion of a plerocercoid larva ofDibothriocephalus latus (formerly Diphyllobothrium latum) by a human results in the development of an adult tapeworm, whereas the ingestion of a plerocercoid larva of a Spirometra species results in the continued existence of the larva (i.e., the sparganum) in the new host (81). This is a situation wherein the human is behaving biologically like a second intermediate or paratenic host. The clinical features of disease are influenced by worm burden (most patients harbor only a single worm), worm location, and worm viability. Proliferative sparganosis can occur rarely with devastating, often fatal, outcomes (82). Spargana migrate, but this migration usually does not cause symptoms. Migration to a subcutaneous location, however, may result in a nodule (44). This nodule may be excised to exclude the possibility of malignancy. Ocular sparganosis, particularly involving the conjunctiva, may result following the application of a folk-medicine poultice that contains raw snake or frog tissues. Inflammation and calcification ensue after death of the sparganum; when these symptoms occur in the brain, they may cause obstructive hydrocephalus (58). Subcutaneous spargana that become exposed through ulceration have been mistaken for Dracunculus in regions where this latter parasite is endemic (44).

row.entry: Usually asymptomatic; heavy infections resemble heavyH. nana infections.
Eggs in the feces; proglottids disintegrate before fecal passage. Egg morphologic details are in the legend ofFig. 22.

Motile proglottids in the stool, similar toD. caninum infection. Proglottid and egg morphology and number of eggs per pouch are used for identification.

sect2.para: a Praziquantel is the treatment of choice for infections with adult tapeworms; it is also effective for treatment of coenurosis. Effective preventive measures are centered on controlling disease in the zoonotic host (e.g., cats or dogs) or controlling the zoonotic hosts themselves (e.g., rats). Controlling intermediate hosts is also effective but may prove more difficult.
b Hymenolepsis nana, the more common species in the genus, is covered in detail in chapter 149 of this Manual.

sect2.title: Direct Examination and Microscopy
sect2.para: Spargana are flat, ribbon-like worms that superficially resemble adult tapeworms (Fig. 21). Closer inspection demonstrates an immature anterior end without hooklets; a cleft or ventral groove, termed a bothrium, is present (83). Mature proglottids are not produced. Histopathologic examination of the sparganum demonstrates calcareous corpuscles characteristic of a cestode. Developed internal organs are not seen, but rather, irregularly scattered smooth muscle fibers and excretory ducts are seen in a loose stroma. The features that help to differentiate sparganosis from metacestode infections caused by Taenia and Echinococcus species are shown in Table 3.

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: If the diagnosis is not suspected, it is usually made when a viable sparganum is unexpectedly discovered during surgery. The gross findings are largely diagnostic, but histopathologic examination can be used for confirmation. In such instances, serology is not useful. However, if this disease is clinically suspected, the diagnosis may be achieved through the combination of radiology and serology (84). Serologic tests for Spirometra are not commercially available, so sera should be sent to specialized centers.

sect2.title: Treatment
sect2.para: Medical therapy is currently deemed unsuitable for the treatment of sparganosis because the plerocercoid larva is resistant to praziquantel. Complete surgical excision is recommended. An incomplete excision, particularly if the anterior end of the larva remains in the tissue, may result in continued growth of the organism (1).

sect2.title: SUMMARY
sect2.para: There are a wide variety of less commonly encountered helminthic parasites, which may be nematodes, cestodes, or trematodes. The diseases caused by these parasites are interesting and demonstrate their highly evolved life cycles and the complex interactions with their hosts. Diseases produced range from subclinical to life threatening. In many instances, the disease occurs only in a particular geographic area which is largely determined by the biological ranges of the definitive and intermediate hosts. Dietary and folk-medicine customs are also important in the prevalence of human disease, as many of these are associated with the ingestion or application of raw animal products. The treatment of these parasites varies depending on the infectious agent, but common preventive measures may significantly diminish the transmission of many of these parasitic diseases. These measures include the zoonotic control of parasitic disease in animal hosts and the vectors of transmission, washing of fruits and vegetables, access to clean drinking water, and thorough cooking of meats before consumption.

figure.title: FIGURE 20 The Spirometra life cycle. Spirometra are cestode parasites of dogs and cats (step 6). Eggs that are passed in the feces must embryonate (steps 1 and 2), then the coracidia are released in an aqueous environment to infect a copepod (3) and transform into procercoid larvae (4). Fish or amphibians that eat the infected crustacean become the second intermediate host, in which plerocercoid larvae are formed. Dogs and cats that eat the infected second intermediate host complete the cycle. Humans similarly become infected by eating or using raw flesh (e.g., folk medicines) from the second intermediate host, or drinking unclean water containing infected copepods (step 8). Image courtesy of DPDx, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx).

FIGURE 21 A sparganum superficially resembles an adult tapeworm. Close inspection, however, clarifies its immature form, with a head with only a ventral groove or bothrium (arrow) and a lack of proglottids. The maximum width is 6 mm. Unstained; original magnification, ×0.5.

table.title: TABLE 3 Differentiating features of metacestode infections

entry.para: Protoscolices or cysticerci are not formed.
Thickened anterior end with cleft-like invagination.
Single cysticercus (i.e., one protoscolex) within bladder wall
Invaginated scolex has a papillary appearance.
A few protoscolices present within bladder wall
Invaginated scolices have a papillary appearance.
Numerous protoscolices within brood capsules that are with a large cyst
Thick cyst wall with single-to-multiple layers, depending on the species
Invaginated scolices with a papillary appearance arenot present.

sect2.para: a Racemose cysticercosis is caused by a rare variant that lacks a cysticerus and has a vesicular multichambered appearance.

figure.title: FIGURE 22 The thick inner membrane of the egg of Hymenolepis diminuta is surrounded by a gelatinous matrix and then by an outer striated shell. The eggs of H. diminuta are spherical, whereas those of Hymenolepis nana are ovoid. The egg pictured here is 80 μm in diameter. Unstained; original magnification, ×250. See chapter 149, “Cestodes,” for more detailed coverage of Hymenolepis spp.
